case_id: Bibi Parwana Khatoon v. State of Bihar (2017) SC 356
facts: Marriage between the deceased (Bibi Tarannum Khatoon) and Md. Allauddin (absconding accused) took place approximately 1.5 years prior to the incident.

Allegations existed that the deceased was subjected to cruelty and torture by her husband, mother-in-law (Bibi Parwana Khatoon - Appellant No. 1), and sister-in-law (Bibi Jannat Khatoon - Appellant No. 2) for non-fulfillment of dowry demands (Rs. 10,000 cash and a Hero Honda motorcycle).
Incident occurred on 19.07.1999 around 10:00 AM at Village Chainpur, P.S. Muffasil, District West Champaran, Bihar.
The deceased was allegedly set on fire after kerosene oil was poured on her by the accused.
FIR was lodged on 19.07.1999 at 14:30 hours by Md. Nasim Akhtar (PW-3, brother of the deceased) based on his 'fardbeyan' recorded at M.J.K. Hospital, Bettiah.
A dying declaration was recorded by the Judicial Magistrate, Bettiah (PW-9) on 19.07.1999 at 2:15 PM.

In the dying declaration, the deceased implicated her mother-in-law (poured kerosene), sister-in-law (lit the matchstick), and husband (caught hold of her), stating the motive was non-fulfillment of dowry demands.
A medical certificate confirmed the deceased was fit to make the statement when the dying declaration was recorded.
Post-mortem examination conducted by Dr. B.N. Prasad (PW-8) revealed 100% burn injuries, with the cause of death stated as shock due to extensive burns.
The Trial Court convicted both appellants (mother-in-law and sister-in-law) under Sections 304B and 498A IPC, sentencing them to 10 years RI and 3 years RI respectively, to run concurrently.
The High Court of Patna dismissed the appellants' appeal and confirmed the Trial Court's judgment.
The present appeal was filed before the Supreme Court by the convicted mother-in-law and sister-in-law.
ipc_sections: Section 498A (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty)
Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention - implicitly applied)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The conviction under Section 304B IPC is valid as all essential ingredients are established: death occurred under unnatural circumstances (burning) within 7 years of marriage, and the deceased was subjected to dowry-related cruelty soon before her death.
precedents: Kans Raj v. State of Punjab (2000) 5 SCC 207 ('Soon before' doesn't mean immediately before, requires proximate link)
State of Punjab v. Iqbal Singh (1991) 3 SCC 1 (Establishes presumption under Section 113B Evidence Act once foundational facts of 304B proven)
Pawan Kumar v. State of Haryana (1998) 3 SCC 309 (Outlines necessary ingredients for Section 304B conviction)
elements: Death of a woman within seven years of marriage
Death caused by burns or bodily injury or occurring otherwise than under normal circumstances
Woman was subjected to cruelty or harassment by her husband or any relative of her husband
Such cruelty or harassment was for, or in connection with, any demand for dowry
Such cruelty or harassment was subjected 'soon before' her death

counter_arguments.loophole: The evidence establishing a proximate and live link between the alleged dowry demand/cruelty and the death ('soon before') is weak or based on general allegations, failing to meet the stringent requirements for the Section 113B presumption.
supporting_precedents: Baijnath v. State of M.P. (2017) 1 SCC 101 (Emphasizes strict proof of cruelty 'soon before death' for 113B presumption)
Surinder Singh v. State of Haryana (2014) 4 SCC 129 (Requirement of proximate link, general allegations insufficient)
Tarsem Singh v. State of Punjab (2008) 16 SCC 155 (Must establish a live link between dowry demands and death)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The dying declaration recorded by the Judicial Magistrate (PW-9) is credible, voluntary, made while the deceased was fit, and directly implicates the appellants, clearly outlining their specific roles in the crime and the dowry motive.
precedents: Laxman v. State of Maharashtra (2002) 6 SCC 710 (Magistrate's recorded dying declaration carries high evidentiary value; doctor's certificate on fitness is crucial)
Paniben v. State of Gujarat (1992) 2 SCC 474 (Principles for assessing reliability of dying declarations; corroboration not essential if declaration is credible)
Khushal Rao v. State of Bombay AIR 1958 SC 22 (Established dying declaration as an exception to hearsay rule, can form sole basis of conviction if reliable)
elements: Mental fitness of the declarant (certified by doctor)
Clarity and consistency of the declaration

counter_arguments.loophole: Despite medical certification, the deceased's condition (100% burns) might have impaired her ability to give a fully accurate or voluntary statement, or she might have been influenced by relatives present before the Magistrate arrived.
supporting_precedents: K. Ramachandra Reddy v. Public Prosecutor (1976) 3 SCC 618 (Court must be satisfied about declarant's mental condition and voluntariness)
State of U.P. v. Madan Mohan (1989) 3 SCC 390 (Need for careful scrutiny, possibility of tutoring cannot be ignored)
Nallapati Sivaiah v. Sub-Divisional Officer, Guntur (2007) 15 SCC 465 (Circumstances like extent of injuries, possibility of influence are relevant)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The testimonies of prosecution witnesses, particularly the deceased's relatives (PW-1, PW-3, PW-5, etc.), consistently prove the history of dowry demands and harassment, corroborating the motive mentioned in the dying declaration and fulfilling the requirements of Section 498A and 304B IPC.
precedents: Girdhar Shankar Tawade v. State of Maharashtra (2002) 5 SCC 177 (Testimony of close relatives is natural and reliable in dowry cases, provided it's credible)
State of H.P. v. Nikku Ram (1995) 6 SCC 219 (Minor discrepancies in witness statements do not vitiate the entire testimony)
Surinder Kaur v. State of Haryana (2014) 4 SCC 129 (Evidence of relatives regarding dowry demands admissible and relevant)
elements: Credibility and consistency of witness accounts
Establishment of cruelty or harassment linked to demands

counter_arguments.loophole: Witnesses being close relatives are 'interested witnesses', potentially biased or prone to exaggeration. Lack of independent, non-related witnesses weakens the corroborative value of their testimony regarding specific acts of cruelty or demands made 'soon before' the death.
supporting_precedents: Suraj Mal v. State (Delhi Administration) (1979) 4 SCC 725 (Testimony of interested witnesses needs careful scrutiny and independent corroboration where possible)
Harmanpreet Singh Ahluwalia v. State of Punjab (2009) 7 SCC 712 (Caution advised when relying solely on testimony of interested witnesses in family disputes)
M. Narsinga Rao v. State of A.P. (2001) 1 SCC 691 (While relationship is not disqualification, prudence requires corroboration for interested witnesses)

defense_arguments.argument: The dying declaration is unreliable, possibly tutored, and inconsistent. The deceased's severe condition (100% burns) raises doubts about her physical and mental capacity to provide an accurate, voluntary statement.
edge_cases: Extreme physical trauma affecting cognitive ability despite a basic fitness certificate.
Possibility of relatives influencing the deceased before the Magistrate's arrival.
precedents: Darshana Devi v. State of Punjab 1995 Supp (4) SCC 126 (Court acquitted based on doubts about dying declaration due to possibility of tutoring and inconsistencies)

Mohd. Arif @ Ashfaq v. State (NCT of Delhi) (2011) 13 SCC 621 (Stresses need for highest standard of scrutiny for evidence like dying declarations in capital cases, principle applies to serious offenses)
Paparambaka Rosamma v. State of A.P. (1999) 7 SCC 695 (Multiple dying declarations with inconsistencies render them unreliable)

defense_arguments.argument: The prosecution failed to establish through credible evidence that the deceased was subjected to cruelty or harassment specifically 'soon before' her death in connection with dowry demands. General allegations of past demands are insufficient to invoke the presumption under Section 113B of the Evidence Act.
edge_cases: Difficulty in defining the precise temporal proximity required by 'soon before'.
Lack of specific incidents of cruelty linked closely to the time of death.
precedents: Baijnath v. State of M.P. (2017) 1 SCC 101 (Reinforces the need for proving a proximate and live link between cruelty and death for Section 304B)
Sham Lal v. State of Haryana (1997) 9 SCC 759 (Presumption under Section 113B is not automatic; foundational facts must be strictly established by prosecution)
Kamesh Panjiyar @ Kamlesh Panjiyar v. State of Bihar (2005) 2 SCC 388 ('Soon before' implies proximity; vague allegations insufficient)

defense_arguments.argument: The primary witnesses are close relatives of the deceased and thus 'interested witnesses'. Their testimony regarding dowry demands and cruelty lacks independent corroboration and should be viewed with caution.
edge_cases: Assessing credibility where only family members can testify about internal family matters.
Distinguishing genuine grievances from potential exaggeration due to animosity after the incident.
precedents: Kali Ram v. State of H.P. (1973) 2 SCC 808 (Burden of proof remains squarely on the prosecution; interestedness of witnesses is a factor in evaluation)
Ganesh Bhavan Patel v. State of Maharashtra (1978) 4 SCC 371 (Emphasizes need for careful scrutiny of evidence from partisan or interested witnesses)
Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab AIR 1953 SC 364 (While relatives can be truthful, their evidence requires careful scrutiny, especially if enmity exists)

judgment.outcome: Appeal Dismissed. Conviction and sentence confirmed.
reasoning: The Supreme Court found the dying declaration recorded by the Judicial Magistrate (PW-9) to be credible, reliable, and untainted. The Magistrate took necessary precautions, and the doctor (PW-8 also testified) certified the deceased's fitness.

The Court held that the dying declaration clearly established the roles of the appellants (mother-in-law pouring kerosene, sister-in-law lighting the match) and the husband (catching hold), along with the dowry demand motive.
The contents of the dying declaration, coupled with the unnatural death (burning) occurring within 1.5 years of marriage, were sufficient to establish the ingredients of Section 304B IPC.

The Court reasoned that the act of setting the deceased on fire, motivated by dowry demands as stated in the dying declaration, itself constituted cruelty 'soon before death', fulfilling that requirement for Section 304B and triggering the presumption under Section 113B of the Evidence Act.
The testimonies of the deceased's relatives (PW-1, PW-3, etc.) regarding prior dowry demands were found consistent and provided corroboration for the motive stated in the dying declaration.
The defense failed to rebut the presumption under Section 113B, Evidence Act, as the prosecution successfully established the foundational facts required under Section 304B IPC.

Arguments challenging the reliability of the dying declaration and the testimony of interested witnesses were considered but rejected based on the specific facts and evidence on record, particularly the clarity and procedural validity of the dying declaration recorded by the Magistrate.
cited_cases: Paniben v. State of Gujarat (1992) 2 SCC 474 (Principles on reliability of dying declaration)
Laxman v. State of Maharashtra (2002) 6 SCC 710 (Value of Magistrate-recorded dying declaration and medical certification)
State of Punjab v. Iqbal Singh (1991) 3 SCC 1 (Presumption under Section 113B Evidence Act)
Kans Raj v. State of Punjab (2000) 5 SCC 207 (Interpretation of 'soon before death')
Khushal Rao v. State of Bombay AIR 1958 SC 22 (Evidentiary value of dying declarations)
Baijnath v. State of M.P. (2017) 1 SCC 101 (Principle regarding 'soon before death' requirement - cited for context of legal standard, though court found it met here)
